column38: Ding et al., 2017 - (looked at native and invasive range n=9 china native and n=10 invasive Australia. 84-96 pupae analysed per colony. China: observed mf=29 range19-45, effective=24.6-arithmetic 21.87-harmonic range 12.24-41.55 n=9. Australia: observed mf=27.4 range 16-42, effective=21-arithmetic 17.85-harmonic range 7.78-38.33 n=10.) Koyama et al., 2009 - (Apis_cerana_japonica. High proportion of workers with active ovaries in queenright colonies. Pamilo method. Artificially create 4 queenless colonies from 4 queenright colonies kept at a university in Tokyo (sample size N=4). Microsatellite DNA markers, analysed 272 workers and 57 queen larvae, 68 workers per colony range 64-80. 14.5 queens per colony analysed, range 8-20.  Kobs = 9 range 7-12, effective mating frequency = 8.88 (harmonic) 9.17 (arithmetic) range 7.15-11.74. Suggest that their estimates could be underestimates due to sampling error and mention that in unpublished data they observed mating frequency to be 11-15 mates. Effective mating frequency calculated using both queens and worker samples); Hughes et al., 2008 - (citing Oldroyd et al., 1998 - n=4, effective mating frequency = 12 (arithmetic). Starr method)

column38: Tarpy et al., 2013 - (Study on commercially reared bees. N=79 colonies, DNA from 30-45 adult workers per colony, mean=39.2, 3098 total. Nielsen method. Mean observed mating frequency = 14.7, mean effective mating frequency = 13.6 (don't know if it's arithmetic or harmonic)). El-Niweiri & Moritz, 2011 - (Apis_mellifer_jemenitica. N=28 wild colonies, 672 workers genotyped, 24 workers per colony. Kobs = 14 range 9-23, effective mating frequency = 13.16 (arithmetic), do not provide colony estimates used to calculate harmonic mean. Lower polyandry in regions with greater rainfall. Pamilo method. Sudan.) Shaibi & Moritz, 2010 - (N=16 colonies sampled from Libya. DNA of at least 24 workers per colony extracted, DNA microsatellite analysis. Does not specify the type of analysis used to determine effective mating frequency. Kobs = 14.58. Effective mating frequency (method used unknown, my value is estimation based on three mean values, type of mean value unknown) = 18.36.). Tarpy et al., 2010 - ('Africanized Honey Bee' from feral population in USA, this species was originally from Africa and hybridised with the bees presen already in the Americas which were from Europe. 3 groups used: control group, managed group and feral bees (N=20) - all my data is just for the feral bee population. Effective mating frequency (feral) = 18.5 (arithmetic) 15.1 (harmonic) range 7-37.53, Kobs = 18.5 range 6-32. Therefore, non-native. 1253 workers genotyped using microsatellite markers, 7-79 per colony, N=20 colonies. Nielsen method.) Hernandez-Garcia et al., 2009 - (Workers collected from apiaries - therefore, not wild. Apis-mellifera_ibiriensis. Starr method. 2127 (915 + 1212) workers genotyped from N=48 colonies, average of 44.31 workers per colony. Kobs = (15.73 n=22 + 18.92 n=26) 17.46 (arithmetic) range 8-29, effective mating frequency = (10.43 n=22 + 12.88 n=26) 11.76 (arithmetic).)

column38: Zhang et al., 2018 - (wild queens collected and then reared. Mating frequency determined from the number of paternal alleles in workers. All queens only mated one wild male. Monogyny is assumed by Zhang). Takahashi et al., 2008 - (Monogynous. DNA microsatellite analysis. N=7 colonies. Queens collected from the wild and put into artificial colonies. 5 colonies were queenright and 2 queenless. The queen, 20 adult workers and 20 adult males were obtained from each colony and genetically analysed and determined whether they were queen or worker derived. Starr method. Monandrous - all queens. Monogynous as well. 4.1% of males were derived from workers. Workers sons only detected in 3/5 of the queen-right colonies. In queenless colonies, workers produced a large proportion of the males 47%. Relatednes =0.74.)

column38: Jaffe et al., 2012 - (citing Paxton et al., 2002; Richards et al., 2005 - Same references as Hughes et al., 2008 plus additional ones, so using this data. Kobs = 1.2, mean effective paternity = 1.07, Starr method, mean number workers analysed per colony = 5, mean queen number = 1. N=52 (Richards et al., 2005) + 16 (Paxton et al., 2002). Citing Paxton et al., 2002 - N=16 colonies used to calculate effective mating frequency. Effective mating frequency = 1.13 (harmonic) 1.25 (arithmetic) range 1-3. Starr method.); Soro et al., 2009 - (N=31 colonies. 148 workers sampled but 130 used for pedigree analysis. Microsatellite markers. For 5/31 nests only one worker was collected (small sample size). Only N=25 nests for which colony structure could be estimated unambiguously and were used in the pedigree analysis. Starr method. Workers are capable of mating. All colonies were monogynous, but queen was absent in 15/31 nests. 56% colonies (14/25) monandrous, 36% (9/25) with two patrilines, 8% (2/25) with three patrilines. Effective mating frequency = 1.24 (harmonic) 1.38 (arithmetic). Kobs = 1.52 range 1-3.); Hughes et al., 2008 - (Richards et al., 2005 - N=52. DNA microsatellite analysis. Starr method. Mean number of workers analysed per colony = 11.38. 41 of 52 colonies was monandrous and monogynous. The remaining 11 colonies had deviation from this structure including: (two egg-laying queens, worker oviposition og gynes and males, alien workers).) Used Soro et al., 2009 and Paxton et al., 2002 to calculate the mean effective mating frequencies

column52: Marting et al., 2018 - (Single peak in size-frequency distibution. No obvious differences in allometric slope in log-log head width-mesosoma plot between potential different castes. Scaling coefficient was significantly higher than the predicted isometric slope of 1 between head width and mesosoma, indicating an allometric relationship between these two variables (slope=1.13). Continuous size distribution with long tail for workers of increasingly large size. Likely that this species show monophasic (linear) allometry. Head size varied from 0.57-1.29mm.)

Continuous polymorphism with differing allometric slopes. Hard to quantify the number of discrete castes but highly polymorphic.); Berghoff et al., 2002 - (The largest worker had a dry weight 115 times greater than the smallest worker and range in body length from 2.3-9.3. Allometric relationship only found for two pairs of body parts: head width - head length + hind tibia length - pronotum width. No break of the allometric regression line was found, therefore this species displays monophasic allometry without distinct morphological subcastes.) Conflict between papers, but I use the results of the morphometric analysis to determine that species has monophasic allometry and is single caste for Caste3

column52: Baudier & O'Donnell, 2018 - (Citing Powell & Franks, 2005; Powell & Franks, 2006; Jaffe et al., 2007 - (Workers are divided into 4 morphologically and behaviourally distinct worker subcastes: minims, media, porters (=submajors?), soldiers.) Subcastes perform distinct roles for their colonies. Identifying worker subcastes: dark sclerotized head capsules were minims and media - 1.11mm head width or below minim 1.11 or above were media. Very few individuals with 1.11-1.12mm. Worker with pale head capsules and non-toothed, sickle shaped mandibles were classified as soldier. Workers with pale head capsules and flat or toothed mandibles were classified as porters. Subcastes differed in head sizes but there was substantiall overlap in size between the three largest subcastes. Head widths: minims - 0.97 +-0.11mm; media - 1.35 +-0.18; porters - 1.97 +-0.28; soldiers - 2.79 +-0.35. N=1167 workers measured in total. N=37 colonies sampled.); Powell & Franks, 2005 - (Presence of distinct submajor caste with distinct prey transport role. They eat large arthropods which are not ants which is derived for the genus - unique for the genus. Significant challenges to the transport of this large prey. Suggest that submajor evolved to overcome them.); Wheeler, 1991 - (Workers appear to be produced through at least 3 and possibly 4 distinct developmental programs and can be considered to belong to 3 or 4 physical subcastes.). Some disagreement between papers - estimated as 4 castes as Wheeler is unsure whether there are 3/4 but Baudier & O'Donnell state as 4.
column53: Holldobler&Wilson, 1990; Baudier & O'Donnell, 2018 - (Citing Powell & Franks, 2005; Powell & Franks, 2006; Jaffe et al., 2007); Powell & Franks, 2005; Wheeler, 1991

column52: Powell & Franks, 2005 - (Less exaggerated submajor caste than E. burchellii.); Feener et al., 1988 - (Distinguish between a polymorphic worker caste and disctinct soldier caste with large mandibles. Mass of workers ranged from 1.8-19.4mg while soldiers ranged from 16-27.4mg. Soldier and worker body mass overlapped by 5%. Allometric relationship between head width and mass: slope changed with inflection point among the worker caste and then change in slope for transition to soldier caste. Body length: similar trend to head width. Other morphometric relationships available.) Very difficult to determine number of different allometric slopes. Powell & Franks suggest that it has a submajor caste so I suggest assigning 4 worker subcastes similarly to Eciton burchellii

They classify media and major as soldiers and minor and small as workers.)

column38: Fraser et al., 2000 - (Microsatellite DNA markers. 13/42 colonies were polygynous - range from 2 to >100 queens per colony. Minority of colonies are polygynous, the great majority of queens live in polygynous colonies. Monandry inferred from the 29 monogynous queens. Families in the 4 polygynous colonies examined differed significantly in caste proportions and in head-width distribution (total = 646 workers, 226 + 178 + 120 + 122). Indicates that genetic rather than environmental cuases for the observed differences between families.)
column52: Fraser et al., 2000 - (Describes the presence of soldiers and minor workers that follow a complex allometry. Clearly bimodal size-frequency distribution, with small number of intermediates. Large head size range from 1.6-5.2mm. Regressions show allometric relationships between head width-total body length, head width-pronotal length. Each curve charaterised by two distinct segments, and therefore allometry in these body parts is diphasic (different slopes between head width-body length; same slope but different y-intercepts for head width-pronotal length). Behavioural analysis reveals division of labour among three physical worker castes. the differences in the behavioural repertories of each of the castes are statistically significant.)

column35: Nielsen method
column38: On average 23 (20-27) individuals per colony sampled (410 workers or brood in total) from 18 colonies. 13/18 clearly monogynous, 5 nests strong suggestion of polygny. To determine the number of patrilines, used the most likley genotype of the mother in monogynous colonies. Used only monogynous colonies. Polyandry in 9/13 colonies (monogynous) range 1-3. Paternal reproductive skew was low on average and observed in all nests. Effective mating frequency (including monandrous queens, n=13): mean harmonic = 1.53, arithmetic = 1.78. Effective mating frequency excluding monadrous queens (which is the figure they give): harmonic = 1.99, arithmetic = 2.12. Observed patriline number=2.8 n=15. Could only indirectly infer queen number using genetic analysis, no queens were recovered

Aron et al., 2016b - (Queen number: mean=1, n=17, 100% monogynous colonies, citing Leniaud et al., 2013; Lenidaud et al., 2015). Leniaud et al., 2015 - (no queen found, so her genotype made up from multilocus offspring genotypes - 201 workers and 203 soliders. Colonies are headed by a single queen. Used 7 colonies. Genotypes consistent with single mother in all colonies. Mating number: observed mating frequency (genetic) mean = 11 range 6-14 males. Patriline skew present and could be 10x. Effective mating frequency = 8.79 (arithmetic) range 3.92-11.46, 7.47 (harmonic). Populations between Merzouga and Amerzgane differ in mating frequency - the ecology of these two populations seems to differ along with colony size and structure). Leniaud et al., 2013 - (soldier and worker caste have different patriline distribution. 240 workers genotyped, N= 10 colonies. Minimum number of queens determined from field observation and from worker genotypes - strictly monogynous. Observed paternity frequency = 5.7 range 3-8, effective mating frequency = 5.08 (does not clarify whether hamonic or arithmetic). Not Thelytokous parthenogenetic.)
column50: 2 or 3 (dividing the continuously polymorphic worker caste as majors and minors?)
column52: Leniaud et al., 2015 - (Polymorphic worker caste along with monomorphic soldier caste. Describes all Cataglyphis as having marked size polymorphism among the worker castes. They describe soldiers as belonging to a 3rd caste, separate from the worker and queen castes - different developmental plan. Citing Molet et al., 2014 - soldier caste undergo different growth rules.); Molet et al., 2014 - (Among workers, size distribution was continuous with the largerst workers heads 194% wider than the smallest - highly polymorphic. Describes large workers as 'major workers' once. Two distinct queen castes. Discrete monomorphic soldier caste. Based on worker growth rules, these rules cannot produce a soldier even when worker size is scaled up - indicating separate caste. Worker allomectric coefficient of 1.1 for thorax-gaster. Allometric growth for many traits in worker caste - table in paper. In C. bombycina, we found that the allometry coefficients (growth rates) of soldiers were never different from either worker or queen castes. Instead, they were sometimes similar to workers, and sometimes similar to queens. Thus, soldiers do not exhibit new growth rates, but they recombine growth rates from both worker and queen castes. In contrast, the elevations of regression lines of soldiers always differed from both worker and queen castes so growth rules were not fully conserved: growth rates were, but critical sizes were not. Soldier and majors may function as repletes.)

column38: Thelytokous but males do exist. Worker produce queens thelytokously when orphaned. Many new colonies are polygnous but monogyny is restored by workers killing queens - Monnin et al., 2018. Aron et al., 2016 - (n=23, paternity frequency (number of males contributing to offspring) = 5.3, 100% queens multiply mated, range 2-8). Lenoir 1988 - (10% 2x mated, 90% queens >2x mated, n=NA). Aron et al., 2016b - (citing Pearcy et al., 2004; Pearcy & Aron, 2006 mean 1.05, range 1-2, n=61, 92% monogynous, 8% polygynous. Additional entry from Aron et al., 2016 citing Lenoir et al., 1988 - mean queen number = 1 n= >100. 100% monogynous).  Doums et al., 2013 - (Thelytokous parthenogenetic but half of females are sexually reproduced. N=18 colonies excavated. Queens identified by dissecting ovaries. Paternity analysis of 475 workers from N = 6 colonies that produced more than 5 'sexually produced' gynes. Mean patrilines per colony in workers = 9 range 5-13, in 'sexual' gynes = 4.5 range 3-7. Mean effective paternity for workers = 5.91 (arithmetic) 5.19 (harmonic), for 'sexual' gynes = 4.35 (arithmetic) 4.02 (harmonic). Observed patrilines = Could this be the result of 'cheating patrilines?' In some colonies males sired disproportionately higher number of gynes compared to workers. Gynes are produced by the queen. Jaffe et al., 2012 - (Pearcy et al., 2009 - Kobs = 4.91, effective paternity frequency = 3.79, Nielsen method, mean number of workers analysed per colony = 28, mean queen number = 1.). Pearcy et al., 2009 - (Significant paternity skew found in 1/5 colonies. N= 23 colonies collected. 673 workers genotyped along with 23 queens. Nielsen method. Mated with 2-8 males. Kobs = 4.91 (harmonic), effective mating frequency = 3.79 (harmonic). They do not provide raw data to calculate my own means.) Fournier et al., 2008 - (N=12 colonies. Nielsen method. DNA microsatellite genotyping. Did not take a random sample of workers for mating frequency analysis - they selected the first 15 workers leaving the nest after sunrise, plus 10-20 randomly chosen workers. Kobs = 10.08 range 7-14, effective mating frequency = 9.44 (unknown) range 5.26-15.53. Authors state that differences between the effective mating frequency estimated in this study could result from differences in sampling method - Pearcy et al., 2004 collected worker from lab reared queen while this study used freshly collected workers from the field and queen replacement is common in this species. All workers however were consistent with single matriline in this colony - all workers were therefore produced by queen-produced queens (parthenogenetically). So colonies appear monogynous but the number of patrilines increases with each new queen.); Hughes et al., 2008 - (Could not find any useful estimate of effective mating frequency in the references of Hughes et al., 2008); USING WEIGHTED MEAN FOR DOUMS ET AL., 2013 AND PEARCY ET AL., 2009

column38: Queens are monogynous. They mate between 1-6 times with mean = 3.43 (Eyer & Hefetz, 2018). Mate 2-8 times with mean 3.73 (Timmermans et al., 2010 study). Aron et al., 2016b - (Mean observed paternity = 4.41, 18% 2x mated, 82% >2x mated. From Timmermans et al., 2010 study which contradicts what is said in Aron et al., 2010). Aron et al., 2016b - (Queen number: mean=1, n=17, 100% monogynous colonies, citing Timmermans et al., 2010). Leniaud et al., 2013 - (citing Timmermans et al., 2010 - patrilines 2-8, effective mating frequency = 3.39 - does not clarify harmonic or arithmetic) Timmermans et al., 2010 - (N=17 colonies collected. DNA microsatellite genetic analysis of workers. 472 workers genotyped for mating analysis. Queen number determined from field observations and comparing pedigree of the queen (when collected) with the workers genetically. When the queen wasn't sampled (n=4), inferred from the genotype of the workers. All queenright colonies were monogynous (13/17) and all worker genotypes could be assigned to the queen present in the colony. Pedigree analysis for Kobs and Starr method with Pamilo 1993 corrected for non-sampling error for effective mating frequency. Kobs = 4.41 (arithmetic) 3.73 (harmonic) range 2-8, effective mating frequency = 3.39 (harmonic) 3.98 (arithmetic) range 1.95-6.99. Estimations made form 11 field colonies and 6 queens returned to the lab. Number of workers genotyped per colony = 27.8 range 8-59. Workers reproduce and lay haploid eggs in queenless colonies, but no evidence of worker reproduction in queenright nests (N=9) although probability of detecting worker produced males was low (29%). Parentage of the males determined by comparison to queen's genotype to determine worker reproduction.

Timmermans et al., 2008 - (Workers do not reproduce in queenright colonies. However, they can lay both male and female eggs in queenless colonies. However, new female sexuals result from sexual reproduction (and unable to tell whether worker derived females turn into queens or workers). N=29 colonies sampled, 8-25 workers (mean=19.6, total=570) per colony and the queen (when found, n=20) were sampled. Mating frequency calculated on the assumption of single matriline - but this was fine as all colonies were monogynous (all workers unambiguously assigned to the queen present in each nest + relatedness between queen and workers not significantly different from 0.5 which is expected under monogyny). Field collections and offspring born in laboratories used - one year after collection a sample of 41 callow workers and the queen from 4 lab colonies were genotyped. Boomsma & Ratnieks, 1996 method and then Pamilo sample size corrected method. 97 males genotyped from N=6 colonies (mean=16.2 per colony) to investigate the possibility of worker reproduction. Ovarian dissection also used to examine worker reproduction - 152 workers from 8 queenright colonies. Queen replacement is unlikley to be common in this species. Relatednes between workers = 0.49 and 0.44 corrected for inbreeding. Kobs = 3.14 (arithmetic) 2.54 (harmonic) range 1-5, effective mating frequency (pamilo, calculated from the combination of field and laboratory samples) = 2.3 (harmonic) 2.56 (arithmetic) range 1-4.65, effective mating frequency (pamilo, inbreeding corrected, calculated from the combination of field and laboratory samples) = 2.75 (harmonic))

Size-based polyethism for foraging - small workers foraged preferentially in the morning, while medium and large forage preferentially at midday and throughout the day.); Nowbahari et al., 2000 - (Similar degree of worker size variation to C. niger, which is high.); Cerdá & Retana, 2000 - (Citing Cerdá & Retana, 1997 - Continuous 22-fold range in body mass.); Cerdá & Retana, 1997 - (Many species of Cataglyphis ants have a monophasic worker polymorphism with limited size variation, in accordance with expectations concerning individually foraging ants, certain Cataglyphis species, such as C. velox, show a broad worker polymorphism. Describes large workers as 'majors' once.); Cronin et al., 2016 - (Citing Cerdá & Retana, 1997 - highly variable workers); Tinaut, 1990 - (Morphometric measurements: Head width: 1.765 +-0.3841, range 1-2.3125 and others available. Catergorises as major and minor caste but with continuous variation. Allometry described only in quantitative terms). Cerdá & Retana mention that many species will have monophasic allometry which likely includes this species - so single caste assigned for Caste3
column53: Cronin et al., 2016 (citing Cerdá & Retana, 1997 + Bocher et al., 2007); Lenoir et al., 2009; Cerdá & Retana, 2000; Cerdá & Retana, 1997

column38: Small sample size. 1/6 were polygynous mean queen number = 1.17. For monogynous queens, mated between 3-5 males, mean = 3.8. Don’t know if there is skew between matrilines. Polygyny first established from field observation then genetically confirmed. When queens absent, colonies defined as polygynous when more than 20% of workers carry alleles distinct from a single mother. Mating frequency determined from mother-offspring genetic inferences

column38: Amor et al., 2016 - (Behavioural observations have shown that excess ergatoid are executed by workers, probably to maintain monogyny. 162 workers, 19 brachypters (short winged queens), and 17 ergatoids were analysed from n=18 colonies. Monogyny in 17/18 colonies, monandry in 6/18, 12/18 colonies queens were inseminated by 2-3 males. In the polygynous colony, the presence of two queens was most likely (mean queen number=1.06). Mean observed mating frequency was 1.79. Mean effective mating frequency was 1.55 (arithmetic) 1.40 (harmonic).) Aron et al., 2016 - (n=6, paternity frequency (number of males contributing to offspring) = 1.17, 17% queens multiply mated, range 1-2). Aron et al., 2016b - (Queen number: mean=1, n=106, 100% monogynous colonies, citing Amor & Ortega, 2014.)

column35: Nielsen method - Leniaud et al., 2011
column37: Aron et al., 2016b; Leniaud et al., 2011
column38: Aron et al., 2016b - (n=23, paternity frequency (number of males contributing to offspring) = 5.77, 3% queens 2x mated, 87% >2x mated, last 10% unnaccounted). Queen number: mean=5.8, range 1-18, n=9, 100% polygnous, citing Leniaud et al., 2011, values relate to number of queens per nest in polydomous colony therefore queen number=52? Polygyny confirmed with genetic analysis). (Suggested to form supercolonies - Cronin et al., 2016.) Leniaud et al., 2011 - (Polygynous and polyandrous Kobs = 5.17 and form supercolonies. Arrhenotokous only. DNA microsatellite. 12 nests collected.  Mean workers per nest genotyped = 21.5, pupae = 23.1. Mean number of queens = 5.77 (for only queenright nests). Effective mating frequency = 4.28 (type of mean unknown). Total workers sampled 258. Minimum queen number determined from field observation. Created experimental nests (23 niger) containing single queen and 100 workers and genotyped brood. Sampled 24 worker pupae from experimental nests for genetic analysis. Nielsen method. 52 niger queens from 9/12 nests excavated. Kobs mating frequency = 2-10 mean = 5.17. Workers laid eggs when queenless. All 12 nests belonged to the same colony - they have no idea of the actual size of the supercolony sampled (there could have been other nests)); Nowbahari et al., 2000 - (1 to 7 queens collected per nest.)
column52: Lenoir et al., 2009 - (Describes as polymorphic.); Nowbahari et al., 2000 - (Monophasic allometry (continuous variation in size with non-isometric growth) along a wide continuum of size among the workers. Head size increased proportionally to thorax width in mature nests. Single slope for regression between interocular distance and pronotum width which differed from unity. The large workers contributed a major part of the nest guarding and foraging activities, whereas small workers mostly performed nursing behaviours. 3 fold size difference between smallest and largest workers. Coefficient of variation of 18 to 24%. Morphometric analysis: interocular distance: 1.62 +- 0.39 n=412, range 0.79-2.58. Other measurements available.)
column53: Lenoir et al., 2009; Nowbahari et al., 2000

column38: Martin et al., 2013 - (Two distinct social forms: monogynous and polygynous (adoption of daughter queens). N=83 colonies, 90% monogynous (83% of which were monandrous), remaining 10% polygynous. As for other populations, monogyny dominates (citing Rosengren et al., 1993; Seppa et al., 2004).) 7 study mounds polygynous, 79 mongynous (83 colonies, 86 mounds). Martin et al., 2012 - (Colonies can be monogynous or polygynous, monandrous or mate two or three times. Study population of N=76, 57 monandrous, 12 double mated, 7 polygynous colonies (3-12 queens per nest). Jaffe et al., 2012 (citing - Hammond & Keller, 2004; Boomsma & Sundström, 1998; Boomsma & Ratnieks, 1996; Sundström et al., 1996 - Kobs = 1.46, effective paternity frequency = 1.25, Pamilo and estimated from relatedness method, mean number of workers analysed per colony = 19, mean queen number = 1). Kummerli & Keller, 2008 - (Studied a polygynous population. Queen number ranges from a few to several hundred individuals. Arithmetic mean queen number = 115.8, 23.6 (harmonic) - personal communication Liatard et al. Effective number of queens contributing to brood production = 23.7 citing Kummerli and Keller, 2007). Effective mating frequency = 1.2 citing Liautard et al., personal communication. Effective queen number smaller in female-producing nests than male-producing: 5.6F, 110.1M, pattern revers in subsequent year: 172.8F, 8.8M. N=24 female nests examined for effective queen number and N=23 for male-producing nests. Microsatellite markers) Haag-Liautard et al., 2008 - (DNA Microsatellite markers. Sample size per nest 14.7 worker pupae n=23 nests, 11.4 for queen pupae n=4, 10.4 for male pupae n=24. To determine queen mating frequency, the content of the spermatheca of all mated queen (8.2 per nest) sampled. Mean number of queens per nest (based on mark recapture) = 252.5 range 5-859. To detect reproductive skew, 9.2 queens per nest were dissected to determine whether they had developed ovaries and sperm in their spermatheca. Dissection revealed that 89% of queens were mated, 66.2% had mated once.2.1% had mated more than twice with a maximum of 4 mates. Mean mating frequency = 1.34 (arithmetic) 1.2 (harmonic). 10% queens lacked developed ovaries, suggesting a small degree of reproductive skew.); Hughes et al. 2008 - (citing Sundström et al., 1996 + Wenseleers & Ratnieks, 2006 - Effective mating frequency = 1.26)

Tawdros et al., 2020 - (No Formica species exhibits obvious worker subcastes. Morphometric analysis of head width and other measurements. No gaps or non-linear transitions in regression slope that would indicate the presence of discrete morphological subcastes. Workers exhibit continuous linear allometric scaling - 'monophasic allometry.' Therefore, lack discrete morphological subcastes.)

column38: Can be facultatively polygynous. Dekoninck et al., 2015 - (Intra-specific variation from monogynous to polygnous. Mostly monogynous for its distribution in Europe. Genetic analysis suggests oligo/polygynous social structure for the majority of nests in a location in Belgium. High within-nest genetic variance indicates that multiple queens contribute to the workers. N=12 colonies sampled. Approximately 20 workers genotyped per nest. For 5/23 nests there was no clear evidence for polygny, for 14 nests workers genotypes originated from two queens and 4 nests from 3 queens. Estimating the minimum number of queens required for the observed genotypes of the workers. These figures are likley to be an underestimate of queen number as they relied on unrealistically high levels of polyandry to satify the levels of relatedness - for reference, effective mating frequencies of this species have been estimated at 1.47. Suggests that all colonies in this study are polygynous. The claim that there are other monogynous wood ant populations elsewhere in Belgium (Flanders - Dekonick et al., 2010)). Jaffe et al., 2012 (citing Walin et al., 1998 - Kobs = 1.48, effective paternity frequency = 1.47, estimated using relatedness method, mean number of workers analysed per colony = 18, mean queen number = 1, N=79.))

Significant paternity skew. The matrilines were differently represented in the workers and sexual offspring. In some monogynous colonies, the patrilines were differently represented in the worker pupae and sexual pupae at the time. Mean effective mating frequency of polygynous colonies = 1.68, monogynous = 2.06-2.61, Kobs 1-6. Nielsen method. N=70 colonies sampled, as shown by genetic analysis. Harmonic mean of one population = 2.2 n=23. n=23. N=23, 19, 22: mean effective mating frequency for diploid individuals = 2.61, 2.18, 2.06. mean effective mating frequency for adult workers = 2.21, 1.81, 1.87. mean effective mating frequency for worker pupae = 2.78, 2.22, 2.25. Very difficult to calculate meaningful statistics from this paper). column38: We confirmed that a supergene with alternate haplotypes—Sm and Sp—underlies this polymorphism in social structure. At least 16.7% of queens from polygnous nests and 9.5% in monogynous nests were mated to two males - given the small number of offspring genotyped these are underestimates. More specific data on each queen available in the paper. Purcell et al., 2015 - (workers collected from 209 colonies from 17 populations. 8 workers genotyped per colony. Analysis to determine the minimum number of queens to produce the workers. They calculate effective queen number - the number of queens per colony that would produce the observed degree of genetic relatedness among workers, assumingan idealized situation where queen number is stable, queens share reproduction equally, each queen mates with one unrelated male, and queens are as related as workers because they stay in their natal colony (Pamilo, 1991). 116/209 colonies were monogynous 56%. Purcell & Chapuisat, 2013 - (max queen number 15 per colony Purcell & Chapuisat unpublished data. Social forms could occasionally transition from one to the other. N=55 monogynous colonies genetically sampled, mean effective mating frequency = 1.08, 5.4% polyandrous. Only calculated for monogynous colonies. Cites Chapuisat et al., 2004 - effective mating frequency = 1.04, 10% polyandrous. Effective queen number in polygynous colonies was 4.3 + 3.9 (unrelated) or 5.3 +5.8 (related).) Castella et al., 2010 - (Described as socially polymorphic with different structures in close proximity. Sampled workers from 19 monogynous colonies and 17 polygynous colonies - doesn't say whether this was intentional or not.); Schwander et al., 2005 - (Shows natural variation in the mate and queen number.) CREATED ARITHMETIC MEAN OF THE TWO UNKNOWN TYPES OF MEAN

column52: Holldobler & Wilson, 1990 - (Classifies as having 2 subcastes.); Fernández et al., 1994 - (Allometric monomorphism, the relationship between the head width and scape length being the closest to polymorphism. Repletes also found. Head width ranges from 0.5-1.33mm although without distinct morphological subcastes, but rather a continuous distribution. Allometric growth between the head and the other measured paramters e.g. femur length and scape length which have allometric slopes quite dissimilar to 1 (0.48 and 0.5). Tendency for the larger workers to be repletes but they can be of all size classes. Size-frequency distribution for head width is unimodal but skewed to the right with considerable size variation. Authors do describe smallest and largest workers as minor and major - direct observation does allow small workers to be distinguished by elongated head and majors haveing a more rounded head, striae and small furrow in the clypeus. These two morphologies constitute the extremes of a dstribution in which the majority of the individuals belong to intermediate castes. Repletes are not a morphological caste, given the size range these present.)

column38: Non-native: Samples taken from native range in Brazil and invasives in USA. Presence of multiple queens per nest was assesed directly through field observation then confirmed genetically when not all workers in a nest could be assigned to a single queen. Estimated mating frequency by creating artificial subcolonies containing a single queen and 100 workers - number of matings inferred by reconstructing parental genotype from mother-offpsring inferences. 0-20 queens typically found in each nest sampled, max 300. Genetically, worker genotypes not compatible with a single queen in any of the nests sampled. Did not calculate effective mating frequency  as all offspring were consistent with only single mating. Polyandry and polygyny were assesed in the non-native range of the species.

column38: Mature colonies typically had one queen, the result of secondary monogyny. Colony founding usually by multiple queens. Queens live within trees, trees had 1-9 queens per tree. Seedlings have multiple queens (87% more than one queen), which is the result of independent fouding by several queens but then workers likely kill off supernumerary queens. There was single case of two queens in one colony but was likely functionally monogynous - both had enlarged gasters but only one was found in proximity to eggs and brood.

column38: Schluns et al., 2009 - (Variation between populations in queen number (proportion of colonies that were polygynous): 4/20 Java, 3/14 Queensland (2 or 3 queens for Java and Queensland per nest), 15/18 Northern territory (up to 5 queens per nest). On average, the queens were not related to each other. Usually monogynous, but mostly polygynous in Northern Australia. Effective queen numbers (corrected for sampling) = 1.88 (arithmetic overall), 1.1 (Java), 1.3 (Queensland), 3.2 (Northern). Microsatellite markers. N=52 colonies sampled from 3 different locations: 20 Java, 14 Queensland, 18 Northern. 16 workers per colony for genetic analysis of sociogenetic structure. Number of matings determined from sperm in spermatheca in addition to using worker genotypes. Pamilo method. Tested for reproductive skew between queens within colonies - significant skew in 3/22 polygynous colonies (but not in Northern colonies). Effective mating frequency (per queen) = 1.29 (arithmetic overall), 1.3 (Java), 1.5 (Queensland), 1.2 (Northern). Proportion of queens polyandrous: 13/18 (Queensland), 6/22 (Java), 15/49 (Northern). Kobs (per queen) = 1.54 (overall), 2.5 (Queensland), 1.3 (Java), 1.3 (Northern). Kobs range = 1-5. No relationship found between polyandry and polygyny.) Jaffe et al., 2012 - (Schluns et al., 2009 - Kobs = 1.7, effective mating frequency = 1.32 n=89. Pamilo method. Mean queen number = 1.87)

column38: Queen number by field observation then genetically confirmed. For monogyne colonies, queen mating frequency determined by mother-offspring analyses infering the number of males and their genotypes from the worker's genotype. Single queen found in 19/50 nests sampled and then genetically confirmed. 21/50 no queen, but genetics showed single queen previously. 10/50 were polygyne 20% confirmed only by the genetic analysis and not observation. 22/40 of the monogyne queens were singly mated - 11 queens with 2 males, 7 with 3, and one queen with 4 males. A high and significant reproductive bias was found in queens. Relatedness still quite high in polygynous colonies - lower effective queen number

column38: Thurin et al., 2011 - (N=26 colonies tourica, N=60 colonies schmitzii, N=66 colonies maura. DNA microsatellite. Created experimental nests containing a single queen (N=145 total, 10 tourica, 73 schmizii, 62 maura). Overall manged to colledt 862 offspring from 34 experimental nests (270 taurica 20-43 per queen 10 nests, 304 schmitzii 10-52 per queen 12 nests, 288 maura 24 per queen 12 nests). Nielsen method. Colony queen number determined from field observation only (N=26 taurica, N=60 schmitzii, N=66 maura). Polyandry in all 3 species detected. Mean absolute mating frequency = 4.9 range 3-11 taura, 3.34 range 1-14 schmitzii, 1.14 range 1-2 maura. Mean effective mating frequency (probably arithmetic, doesn't say, nor are individual colony estimates given) = 2.91 range 1.8-7 taura, 2.62 range 1-11.2 schmitzii, 1.10 range 1-1.8 maura. Citing Trontti et al., 2007: 224 offspring genotyped from N=18 queens, mean absolute mating frequency = 2.89 range 1-6, effective mating frequency = 2.37 range 1-3.9. Mean number of queens per colony (harmonic, individual colony estimates not provided) = 1.38 range 1-5 n=26 taurica, 1.9 range 1-28 n=60 schmitzii, 1.2 rnage 1-10 n=66 maura, (citing Passera, 1969: 23.6 range 15-200 n=200 pygmaea). All 3 species had high levels of inbreeding which reduces the effect of polyandry and their mates were related. Colony relatedness remained high (>0.5). All 3 more than 50% were polyandrous, more than 90% for taurica and schmitzii.)

column52: Higashi & Peeters, 1990 - (Workers display considerable size variation but relative growth among workers is not allometric. Describes workers as monomorphic, although they fall into 2 obvious size classes which overlap broadly - approaching bimodality. Considerable variation in size: length 13-36mm. Presence of size polyethism - larger workers were engaged in hunting, defence and extranidal building, while smaller workers excavated soil from inside the nest. Log-log regression equation roughly equal to 1 (0.94). Almost no divergence takes place with an overall increase in size.)

Dietemann et al., 2002 - (Citing Gray, 1971 - monomorphic with little size variation of workers.); Gray, 1971 - (Workers show monomorphic polymorphism with limited size range. Morphometric measurements made. Unimodal to bimodal size frequency distributions. Intranidal allometric variation or worker polymorphism was not discernible morphologically.)

Morphometric measurements of head width, pronotum, and fourth abdominal segment. Frequency distribution of worker body size was almost unimodal with small range of variation 2.7-3.5mm in head width. Isometric growth between head width and pronotum width but allometric growth between abdomen width and pronotum width (1.31). Abdomen width increasing faster than pronotum width. Larger individuals had greater potential for egg laying as they had larger number of ovarioles.); Gray, 1973 - (Worker monomorphism with limited size variability.)

column52: Dietemann et al., 2005 - (Workers show a clear bimodal size distribution.); Dietemann et al., 2002 - (Worker size varies over a wide range 14-23mm, exhibiting a bimodal distribution with either very little or no overlap. Growth is monophasic and only slightly allometric. Head width was bimodal in size based on measurements of 157 workers. Slightly allometric growth of outerorbital distance against length as slope was 0.93 and significantly different from 1. Slope and intercept of small and large workers did not differ significantly for allometric plot. Gaster width increased allometrically in relation to outerorbital distance with slope of 0.79. No significant differences though in slope of intercept for small and large workers. Suggests that difference between the small and large caste is result of a change in only the critical size in development rather than different growth rate. Both small and large workers layed trophic eggs.)
Gray, 1971 - (No polymorphism detected.)

column38: Qian et al., 2012 - (DNA microsatellite markers. Queens within polygynous colonies generally unrelated. Queen number ranged 1-4 with 30 functional queens in total, 11/14 colonies were polygynous (78.57%) with mean = 2.1. Queen mating with 1-9 inferred mates with mean = 2.5, 1-11.4 effective mates with mean = 2.4 (arithmetic), 1.78 (harmonic). Polygyny and polyandry. Significant maternity and paternity skews, with 4/11 polygynous colonies having maternity skew. 16 nests sampled from N=14 colonies, 319 workers analysed, 17-36 per nest. For 6/30 inferred queens (20%), the observed paternity was smaller than the effective mating frequency. However, was minimal in most cases, implying that sample sizes were generally sufficient. Paternity skew detected in 5/14 colonies.)

column52: Dijkstra et al., 2005 - (citing Wetterer, 1999 - "leafcutter ants show conspicuous size polymorphism, but sub-castes generally do not have discrete size ranges due to the occassional occurrence of intermediate individuals". Dijkstra distinguish between small, medium and large workers in Atta but only between small and large in Acromyrmex.); Howe et al., 2016 - (Classed as minor, media and major workers for the study citing Larsen et al., 2014 for classification. minors<1.22; 1.6<media<2; 2<majors.); Larsen et al., 2014 - (3 morphological castes with majors being most aggressive towards non-nestmate workers. Major and media workers differ in their propensity to attack based on different decision rules, while minor workers are less sensitive to the differences between nestmate and non-nestmate. Dedicated soldier caste, like in Atta, is absent in Acromyrmex. Images show size disparity between the 3 proposed subcastes.); Ivens et al., 2009 - (Body size variation among minor Acromyrmex workers is considerably larger than among major workers, large minors have sometimes been considered to be a medium-sized worker castes - citing Bot & Boomsma, 1996. Citing Wetterer, 1999 - showed that media workers are merely the tail end of a skewed size distribution of the minor caste. Media have never been observed to forage in the field, pooling them with minors was appropriate in the present study. We used equal mixtures of minors and media to have the entire size range of minors represented.); Hughes et al., 2003 - (Produce size-frequency distributions for n=5 colonies based on head width. Colonies tended to produce probably a single peak with long skewed distribution to the right. Authors classify workers into two subcastes, similar to other species of Acromyrmex.); Poulsen et al., 2002 - (Citing Wetterer - 3rd caste referred to as media caste, but has since been shown not to represent a distinct caste.)

Peeters et al., 2013b - (Potentially: In addition to workers and queens, there is a 3rd caste that is intermediate in size, weight and morphology and lays many unfertilized eggs that are mostly eaten by larvae. This caste is a patchwork of queen-like and worker-like traits which reflects partial activation of queen development. They lack a spermatheca and so are not ergatoid queens. Suggest that they are a soldier caste with a specialized trophic function. Gaster is particularly big. Intermediates much more efficient at laying eggs than workers. Shares many characteristics with the soldier caste in other ant genera.)

column38: In Boyle et al., 2018 likely to get an underestimate due to low proportion of workers sampled per colony. N=14 (polygyny) n=9 (polyandry). Does not use effective mating frequency so cannot definitively classify (4.6 mates per queen). Does not say the proportion of colonies that were polygnous. Disproportionate reproduction between queens (mean 68% by one queen). Rubin et al., 2013 - (DNA microsatellite genotype males to reconstruct queen genotypes. Frequently secondarily polygynous with close relatives and sometimes unrelated queens. Queens were polyandrous in both monogynous and polygynous colonies. Collected 20 workers and 20 males from each tree sampled. Assume fewest queens as possible to give rise to the male genotypes. 11-36 workers per colony, 13-60 males genotyped per colony. Minimum number of mates per queen not clear in colonies with high queen number. Kummerli & Keller, 2007 method for effective queen number. N=8 colonies used, 185 workers 297 males. 3 colonies monogynous, 5 polygynous, mean = 3.25 range 1-9. N= 4 colonies (5 queens in total) for determinig mating frequency (can only use colonies with two queens or less). Mean effective queen number = 2.35 n=8 (producing diploid offspring), 7.71 n=5 (producing haploid offspring)

column38: N=8 colonies developed by one mated queen after their nuptial flight. Observed multiple queens in the field. Co-exist harmoneously even in the presience of newly emerged workers in lab experiments. Dealated queens are relatives in a mature field colony (mean relatedness between pairs of queens = 0.6697 from 5 nests). Identiffied effective paternity using DNA markers as well as counting and comparing sperm numbers in the queen's spermatheca. Reproductive skew identified in 2/5 of the field colonies. Reproductive skew tested under laboratory conditions - exclusive possesion of reproduction not observed in laboratory skew experiments. Sperm counts suggest that queens store sperm from 2-4 males.

column52: Heinze et al., 1999 - (Distinct female caste which appears to be specialized in morphology and behaviour for the production of unfertilized eggs. In queenless colonies, males are reared from these eggs. Small worker weight = 0.72 +- 0.17mg, n=150. Large workers weight = 2.2 +- 0.37mg, n=8. Large workers significantly different to queens (5.3mg). Body size and weight of large and small workers did not overlap. Picture available. Large workers lack a spermatheca, unlike the queen. Large and small workers lay eggs in colonies with and without queens. A role of large workers in colony defense or as repletes for the storage of fat or liquid food could be excluded.); Peeters et al., 2013b - (In addition to workers and queens, there is a 3rd caste that is intermediate in size, weight and morphology and lays many unfertilized eggs that are mostly eaten by larvae. Carlin, 1981- (All but one of the known species of this genus are monomorphic except versicolor, which possess a distinctive major caste. Minors possess long slender mandibles with pointed apical teeth. Majors have massive relatively short mandibles with blunt recessed apical teeth and disproportionately developed mandible muscles. The minor workers were arbitrarily divided into minor and media subcastes based on size. Majors represent distinct caste based on morphological and behavioural grounds. Minor and media repertoires are fairly similar.)

Some newly emerged queens adopted into natal nest in experimental colonies. Described as secondarily polygynous.)

column35: c - observation of single mating and queen number
column38: Lab experiments use to observe which queens in the nest reproduce (=shed wings and begin to lay eggs). This was always (n=13) a single queen and it was always the first queen to emerge except in one case where two queens emerged on the same day. Only the single wingless queen of each colony was reproducing and had elongated ovarioles with several large eggs. 12/14 of the natural colonies had a single wingless queen. Possible oligogyny - mutually intolerant queens space out in the same nest or they engage in fatal fighting - works are tolerant to both. Monandry is likely as a single male usually remains and mates within the nest and they engage in fatal fighting with other males, though genetic proof is lacking.

column38: Trettin et al., 2016 - variation in social forms: several equally reproductive queens (facultative polygyny) in Central and Northern Europe while functional monogyny in peripheral populations in Spain. Variation in the reproductive skew of the queens based on location: boreal and temperate Eurasia colonies have equal skew, range margin colonies (Spain and Japan) have heirarchies and functional monogyny. Mating behaviour differs as well between Spain and Central Europe. Reproductively active determined by ovary dissection. 80% (43/54) of inner Iberian colonies functionally monogynous - only one queen of several in a nest had elongated ovarioles with traces of previous reproduction - the remaining 11 were (n=5) monogynous or (n=6) queenless. Pyrenean colonies - 6/12 were polygynous, 4/12 monogynous, 2/12 queenless. Walter & Heinze, 2015 - (Collected 71 colonies from Poland, 21/71 polygynous.). Friend & Bourke, 2012 - (facultatively polygynous. 20-50% colonies polygynous, 2-5 queens per colony, 95% of which are singly mated (citing Heinze et al., 1995; Bourke et al., 1997; Hammond et al., 2001,2006). Detected reproductive queens by observing egg laying in petri dish when separate from colony for 24 hours, then confirmed with dissection.) Gill & Hammond, 2011 - (Functionally monogynous population from Spain. N=33 colonies.) Gill et al., 2009 - (Functionally monogynous form in Spain. When monogynous and polygynous colonies raised in lab environment, social oragnisation does not change, suggesting a genetic component.); Hughes et al., 2008 - (citing Hammond et al., 2001 - 95% queens were singly mated and 5% were doubly mated. Analysed 79 dealate queens and their stored sperm and 11 monogynous and 9 polygynous colonies. Corrected population mean mating frequency = 1.06); Jaffe et al., 2012 - (citing Hammond et al., 2001 - Effective mating frequency = 1.09. Kobs=1.06. Number of queen-mate pairs = 79 from 42 colonies. Average number of workers analysed per colony = 24. 95% singly mated and 5% doubly mated. Mean queen number =  2.1. Relatedness method to calculate effective mating frequency.)

column38: N= 9  only found single queen colonies. Performed DNA Microstellite analysis but only gave crude estimate of genetic colony struture. Mean relatedness =0.627 which was not significantly different from 0.75 expected for monogyny and monandry however, in 3/8 colonies they found 2 or 3 individuals with genotype at one locus that was not compatible with monogyny and monandry. Active slave raiding may responsible for these additional genotypes of workers that did not match the monogynous and monandrous sociogenetic structure that is typical for this genus. This result is found in a large fraction of M.ravoui colonies

column38: Suni & Eldakar, 2011 - (Monogynous description. Dependent-lineage mating system - must mate males of the other type to produce workers. Mating between types of lineages may not be random? Estimates to date have used only workers to estimate the mating frequency of their mother (Volny & Gordon, 2002; Suni et al., 2007) which is not the true mating frequency because it disregards her mates of the same lineage, which produce gynes. This study uses both workers and gynes. Collected on average 17 workers, 16 gynes from N=16 colonies (8-20 workers, 14-20 gynes) for total 280 workers, 284 gynes. Collected 7 males from 51 colonies, total = 357 - used to determine genotype of colony queens. DNA microsatellite. Nielsen method. Calculated effective mating frequency separately for workers and gynes and then added together. column38: Populations where there are predominantly either monogynous or polygnous colonies - behaviour and genetics are linked. Microsatellite analysis showed that in one population 75% of colonies at Lake Henshaw are monogynous, while Pine Valley 92% polygnous Overson et al., 2016. Haney & Fewel, 2018 used Microsatellite markers of males in the colony to determine whether the colony was polygnous. 14/18 colonies at Pine Valley were polygnous while 3/17 at Lake Henshaw Hanes & Fewel, 2018. Precise queen number calculated for 10 colonies at Pine Valley due to lack of sample size in the other 4. mean=4.1 n=10 range 2-8 but this is only for the colonies that were polygynous at Pine Valley. These colonies are polygynous at maturity, instead of practicing pleometrosis only, in which queens cooperate until worker eclose, at which cooperation breaks down and queens engage in battles until there is a single queen.                  Overson et al., 2016 - (striking differences in queen behaviour and colony structure over its range. Usually monogynous, but in one population they show group colony-founding and likely persists into reproduction. These groups of queens appear to be unrelated, and represent long-term associations of non-family groups and mixed paternity offspring. DNA microsatellites markers. N=16 - estimated relatedness across 16 foundress associations, 2-7 queens per association, mean=3.1. Male genotypes used to detect number of matrilines. Males from 12 colonies per focal population collected, 3 focal populations used. Just assessed monogyny or polygyny, not queen number. Worker production of adult males has never been observed, even in queenless lab colonies. Mating structure - analysed 15, 11, 10 (N=36) colonies from 3 different populations using 20-50 workers from each colony. In colonies that were likely polygynous, queens were isolated in lab and offspring produced there were genotyped. Analysed polyandry normally when monogyny had first been detected. Calculated the observed mating frequency then all three kinds of effective mating frequency - starr, pamillo, nielsen - however, pamillo and nielsen didn't work and produced erroneous values of high mating frequency. Occurred when high numbers of patrilines detected when sample size was small. Majority of colonies from HAZ and HCA populations were monogynous (9/12, 10/12) while only 1/12 was monogynous in PCA. Mean observed mating frequency across all 36 colonies was 8.81 males, with (Starr) mean effective mating frequency of 9.09 (arithmetic - my own calculation) 8.22 (arithmetic - calculated by the paper, seems wrong?) 5.58 (harmonic). Possibly the species with the highest levels of polygyny and polyandry to date.)

column52: Borgesen & Jensen - (Presence of repletes which nourish the queen when she is unable to feed from larval secretions. Repletes have greatly distended gasters and are a specialized group of brood-tending workers. Are they actually a physical caste though? - have they undergone a different developmental pathway to other workers in the colony?); Borgesen, 2000 - (Describe repletes as a temporary caste - young workers who remain in the nest and store liquid nourishment. Workers are monomorphic; they are almost all of the same size, but have a cyclic weight and size gain related to the brood cycle. The largest workers hatch ar the same time as the new reproductives. The smallest workers hatch about 6 weeks after the mating of the young sexuals. Repletes are usually recruited from the largest workers, but within the sample size no significant difference was detected. Head width should be used as a measure in the future.); Elen et al., 2006 - (Workers described as completely sterile. Divide workers into three behavioural tasks (temporal castes) - nurses, repletes, foragers.); Jackson et al., 2007 - (Monomorphic); Wilson, 1953 - (Claims that it is possible that many species of Monomorium are monomorphic.)

column52: Chiu et al., 2020 - (Continuously polymorphic. Size-dependent caste polyethism, large workers performed with higher efficiency and preferred to deliver heavier seeds. Head width: 0.79 mean +- 0.06 SD, n=600 from 28 colonies. Citing Wilson, 1978 - continuous but weakly bimodal frequency distribution. More polymorphic than other species of fire ants. Small group of much larger workers (head width>1.31) have been labelled as soldiers and are charaterized by very large quadrangular heads with strong and highly incurved toothless mandibles. Classifications can be problematic because of the varying size distributions between colonies.) Rajakumar et al., 2018 - (Classifies as minor worker and soldier sub-castes. Displays images of very dimorphic castes. Small round head and large square head. Sigmoidal log-log head body allometry. Classifies as 2 sub-castes.); Wheeler, 1991 - (Increase in head size with body size is linearly allometric.); Ferster et al., 2006 - (Citing Tschinkel et al., 2003 - Continuously polymorphic with seed milling caste. Allometric growth has resulted in large-bodied workers with disproportionately large heads. Analysis showed two modal morphologies in the worker caste, although the distinction was less pronounced than in P. badius.); Wilson, 1953 - (Monophasic allometry over a considerable size range with bimodal size frequency distribution.) Use results from Rajakumar et al., 2018 (2 castes) - just because Wilson only found monophasic allometry in his study doesn't mean non-linear allometry can't exist in the species.

Only one or a few dominant queens have developed ovaries and lay eggs in the nest. Only inseminated queens engage in aggressive interactions) Satoh & Ohkawara, 2008 - (Multiple queens but inseminated queen behave aggressively towards each other and form dominance hierarchies, in which only a few dominant queens developed their ovaries and laid eggs. The system is very similar to functional monogyny. N=24 colonies collected. Dissection to determine reproductive status. Mean dealate queen number = 6.3 (lowest point in the year = 2.4) range 1-76. 87.5% of dealates were inseminated and 27.8% had developed ovaries.)

column38: Genetic analysis revealed a single queen in all colonies and 1-7 patrilines (3.8 mean observed frequency and 2.56 mean arithmetic effective mf, range 1-4.35, harmonic mean effective mf = 2.01). The most productive colonies (in terms of making new workers) had fewer patrilines. Monitored n=14 colonies (8 and 6). Patriline and queen number inferred from n=9 colonies with 30 workers per colony. Males produced parthenogenetically by the queen. Total of 242 workers and 13 males from 9 colonies analysed. Reproductive skew for males present - in colonies with 4 of more patrilines, a single male sired an average of 44% of offspring. Cahan & Helms, 2014; Bespalova & Helms, 2014 - (Variation in social structure exists within this species (queen number - functional polygyny, multiple queen founding then fatal fighting until monogyny, single queen founding) cites Helms & Helms Cahan, 2012 - needs to be checked.)
column52: Rissing & Polloek, 1984 - (Worker size is highly variable; the allometric coefficient (0.93), however, is near unity. As such, this species represent a relatively 'primitive' yet common form of polymorphism in ants according to Oster & Wilson, 1978. Size-frequency distribution shows only 1 clear peak but with wide size distribution (head width and thorax length) with largest workers having head sizes nearly twice the size of the smallest workers. Describes "majors" in quotation marks.); Davidson, 1978 - (The maximum variation in body length measured in this study is over twofold (3.5mm-8.4mm). Describes as having worker size polymorphism. Morphometric data on mandible length. Describes this species as having 'various castes' and also describe its ability to shift caste ratios.); Rissing, 1987 - (Primitively polymorphic; workers are monophasically allometric. There is little, if any, morph-specific task specialization by workers. Considerable variance among workers of a single colony. Size-frequency plots show that proportions of worker sizes change throughout the year, usually with a single peak, but varying degrees of variance in worker size - sometimes very large. Morphometric data on head width but hard to understand.); Davidson, 1977a - (Continuously size polymorphic.)

column38: Collected over 200 colonies in French Guiana and only ever found monogynous nests when queenright. Facultative polyandry reproted in Brazil in separate study. Oliveira et al., 2011 - (Queen number varies in Brazil, monogynous and polygynous exist in sympatry at Cadoso island citing Camargo, 2002. Dissection revealed queens in polygynous colonies are inseminated, have developed ovaries and produce eggs. Behavioural observations showed reproduction in polygynous colonies mediated by agonistic queen interactions and egg cannibalism. Despite open hostility, multiple queens generally successful at depositing egg on egg pile. Queens never seen destroying newly-laid eggs. Dominant queens usually produce more eggs. Polygyny may result from groups of cofounding queens or from adoption of newly-mated queens. N=19 colonies. All dealate queens from n=7 colonies dissected to determine reproductive status. Mean dealate queens per colony (including queenless nests) = 3.79. 10/19 polygynous. Almost all queens laying eggs in the polygynous colonies studied behaviourally.)

column38: Described as facultatively polygynous citing Fresneaue, 1984. Nests are usually monogynous, but sometimes polygynous. Colonies collected from 3 populations. Reproductive queens identified by behavioural comparisons during the experiment and then dissection afterwards. N=12 colonies, 8/12 functionally monogynous, 4/12 effectively  polygynous with 2-4 queens per colony. Behavioural identification of queens did not always match dissection analysis. Genetic analysis showed 5/12 nests were effectively mongynous, only 1-2 males per colony mated all the reproductives, all queens identified as monandrous except from one colony. All gynes were re-adopted daughters. Different methods gave different quantitative results but confirm polygyny. Mean (genetic) number of queens = 2.17 (rough estimate as their estimates were not all precise)

column37: Hanna et al., 2014; Loope et al., 2014 - (Hanna et al., 2013)
column38: Normally monogynous, but polygynous in non-native range. 20% of colonies of invasive Hawaii population contain queens that are not close relatives. Observation of multiple queen colonies early in the season before the new queens are produced implies that foreign queen have been accepted Gambino et al., 1990 + Gambino, 1991. In native range, females are polyandrous and monogynous while in non-native they are often polygynous. Effective mating frequencies use Nielson' method. Effective mating frequency only able to be determined from monogynous colonies. Mean effective paternities between the native and non-native populations were marginally significantly different. Effective mating frequency was higher than the mate number indicating that sample size probably wasn't large enough in the Hawaiian population to fully determine patriline number. Loope et al., 2014 - (Hanna et al., 2013 - Mean effective mating frequency = 2.44 (harmonic), observed paternity frequency = 4.33, n=18.)
